title-group.article-title: Letter to the Editor: Conclusions based on in vitro GME studies using different oxygenator blood flow limitations

author-notes.corresp: Mr. Gerard Myers Halifax Nova Scotia Canada B2W 3Z4 Email: edit@ns.sympatico.ca

body.p: The conclusions found by Dogal and coworkers are inaccurate.1 The authors seemed to lose sight of the fact that the KIDS D100 is specifically a neonatal oxygenator with a maximum rated blood flow of 700 mls/min, while the other two devices (RX05 and Quadrox i) are rated for maximum blood flows of 1500 mls/min.

Running one oxygenator at its maximum flow and the others at half the maximum flow will result in unequal and misleading results when measuring GME activity. An almost exact comparison to this study was done by Melchior.2 The authors’ flawed data in that study compared the KIDS D100 at maximum rated flow to the RX05 and FX05 at only 50% of their maximum rated flows. Investigators cannot run one device at the maximum flow and the others at half flow then make conclusions about their GME handling ability based on those findings.
A more accurate and fair conclusion based on the analysis of their own data would have been to compare post arterial filter GME activity at 50% of rated blood flow in all three oxygenators studied.
